Description: Scout Activity Centres thrive on team work, friendship and outdoor adventure. Develop your campsite management skills and help the centres continue to inspire.
Completion Rules: 3 from Core Requirements + 4 from Activity Centre Skills
Requirements:
Core Requirements (complete 3):
1. Help the warden or manager and work for at least five days at a  permanent District, County or National Scout campsite.
2. Explain and show how to use three items of equipment that you've used in your work with the activity centre.
3. Talk about developments and improvements you would like to see at a permanent campsite.

Activity Centre Skills (complete 4):
1. Explain & demonstrate the use of computers in campsite management
2. Explain & demonstrate how to take care of campers' needs while respecting wildlife
3. Explain & demonstrate how to prevent frozen pipes and what to do if an overground pipe bursts or leaks
4. Explain & demonstrate the need for good site drainage and clear ditches
5. Explain & demonstrate rubbish disposal and how to recycle materials wherever possible
6. Explain the reasons for having clean toilets
7. Explain & demonstrate how to unblock a drain
8. Explain & demonstrate how to use and maintain equipment for an activity you have become familiar with
9. Explain other important tasks that the warden or manager has pointed out

Badge Name: Air or Sea Navigation Activity Badge
Description: Be the one who knows the way to go – at sea or by air. Learn a skill that would help you navigate your crew on your journey.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Air Navigation:
1. Using simple diagrams, illustrate latitude and longitude.
2. Using a compass, show how an aircraft can be turned on to various compass headings.
3. Show that you understand how a compass works, including the difference between magnetic, true and grid north.
4. Explain what magnetic deviation is and how it applies to air navigation.
5. Show that you know about the latest developments in electronic navigation aids.
6. Headings and corresponding tracks.
7. Topographical air map
8. Draw the track between any two places at least 100 nautical miles apart.
9. Show that you can calculate overhead flight times

Sea Navigaton:
1. Gain a good working knowledge of charts, chart datum and symbols used.
2. Complete two positioning tasks
3. Show your skills in compass work by completing three tasks
4. Learn how to use tide tables and tidal stream atlases.
5. Learn how to use the marine log to obtain distance run and speed.
6. Show you understand the buoyage system for United Kingdom coastal waters and other methods of marking dangers and channels.
7. Show that you’re aware of the latest developments in electronic technology, like the Global Positioning System and electronic charts.
8. Go on a coastal voyage of between four and six hours and act as the navigator.

Description: Discover one of man’s greatest accomplishments – developing the technology to fly through the air.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Research one historical aspect of flight, and share what you find out with the Troop.
2. 2. While you’re doing your research, visit at least one place of interest that relates to your chosen subject.
3. 3. Present what you have found out.

Description: Take up your binoculars, observe the skies, and learn to recognise an Airbus from a Boeing
Completion Rules: 1 from  + 1 from  + 1 from Category A + 1 from Category B
Requirements:
(complete 1):
1. Learn to recognise 38 out of the 50 aircraft listed in The Scout Association's Aircraft Recognition List

 (complete 1):
1. Describe the main features you would use to recognise six aircraft, which have been chosen by an appropriate adult.

Category A (complete 1):
1. By yourself or with another Scout, take photographs or collect pictures of at least 10 different aircraft types.
2. Visit an airfield or airport viewing area, for at least an hour.

Category B (complete 1):
1. Recognise and name the national aircraft markings, both service and civil, of at least six countries including the United Kingdom.
2. Learn the RAF and NATO system of letter designation according to aircraft function.
3. Name three basic training aircraft used in private flying.

Description: Develop your angling acumen, the sense of pride from reeling in a big catch to the enjoyment from being outside and close to the water’s edge. This badge is endorsed by The Angling Trust.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Learn the water safety rules and the proper precautions to take when fishing from the bank, shore line, or from a boat.
2. 2. Understand how the Countryside code should be followed by anglers, and where and how to fish legally.
3. 3. Explain how different species of fish have different habitats.
4. 4. Learn about invasive species and make sure to check, clean, and dry your equipment to stop them spreading.
5. 5. Learn the basic hygiene precautions to take when fishing.
6. 6. Go fishing at least four times in two different places.
7. 7. Choose the correct equipment and method for where you plan to fish.
8. 8. Show you can cast correctly and accurately into a target area a suitable distance away, depending on the equipment you are using.
9. 9. Show how to correctly handle a fish, unhook it and return it into the water.

Description: Express yourself! Stretch your imagination and discover the artist within you.
Completion Rules: 3 from Group 1 + 1 from Group 2 + 4 from Group 3 (Required)
Requirements:
Group 1 (complete 3):
1. Paint, draw or illustrate a scene from a story
2. Paint, draw or illustrate a person or object
3. Paint, draw or illustrate a landscape

Group 2 (complete 1):
1. Show a selection of your own recent work.

Group 3 (Required) (complete 4):
1. Choose a favourite art form or artist to take an active interest in.
2. Describe two visits you have made that are connected to your interest.
3. Show that you know a lot about an aspect of your interest.
4. Make a list of major events, exhibitions or venues connected with your chosen subject.

Description: Wipe the sweat from your brow, as you close in your personal best. Athletics is all about practising, persevering and improving – perfect for a Scout like you.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Run through an appropriate warm-up and warm-down routine using all the main muscle groups. Explain why both routines are important.
2. Talk about the safety rules in athletics, particularly throwing and jumping events.
3. Take part in six athletics events.
4. 4. Find out and explain to your leader how to take part in athletics in your local area.

Description: Go the extra distance with the Athletics Plus badge and reach new heights.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Run through an appropriate warm-up and cool-down routine using all the main muscle groups. Explain why both routines are important.
2. 2. Talk about the safety rules for athletics, particularly throwing and jumping events.
3. 3. Compete in any three events (two track and one field, or vice versa) and gain the points set out as indicated on the score chart below.

Description: Get Up and have fun in the great outdoors. Forge new skills as you camp under canvas for at least 15 nights.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Camp as a Scout for at least 15 nights
2. 2. Lead a group of Scouts in the pitching, striking and packing of a four to six-person tent.
3. 3. Find out what to look for when choosing a campsite and in deciding the best position to pitch tents.
4. 4. Show that you understand and act on the reasons for hygiene and the importance of being safe and tidy in camp.
5. 5. Show how you store food hygienically at camp.
6. 6. Learn how to dispose of your rubbish safely and responsibly.
7. 7. Construct two useful camp gadgets.
8. 8. Plan a full menu for a weekend camp. Cook a least one full meal over an open fire.
9. 9. With others in your Troop, plan and carry out a programme of activities for a weekend camp.

Description: From stalactites to stalagmites, experience a different world underground and explore fascinating cave formations
Requirements:
1. Take part in at least four trips to at least two different cave systems.
2. Keep a record of your trips and the routes you followed
3. Develop a good knowledge of the caving and cave conservation codes

Description: Plan and produce a tasty menu for your Scout troop after they come back after a long day of activities.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Plan a menu for a weekend event for between four and six people.
2. Show how and where to shop for the food and the best way to transport it.
3. Show how to store food properly, hygienically and in ways that prevent food poisoning.
4. Cook and serve at least one of the meals from your menu.
5. Demonstrate the best way to clear up afterwards.

Description: Plan and produce a tasty menu for your Scout troop after they come back after a long day of activities.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Plan a menu for a weekend event for between four and six people.
2. Show how and where to shop for the food and the best way to transport it.
3. Show how to store food properly, hygienically and in ways that prevent food poisoning.
4. Cook and serve at least one of the meals from your menu.
5. Demonstrate the best way to clear up afterwards.

Description: Come and join the big top, be the star attraction, and entertain with your ace circus skills.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Take part in two circus skills
2. 2. Carry on putting effort into your two selected skills and show some  achievement.
3. 3. Demonstrate your two selected skills in front of an audience.
4. 4. Find out things about circus life and talk about these with an adult.
5. 5. Watch at least two circus or street performance events.

Description: Climbing requires an inner determination to reach the summit, communication skills and working as part of team - perfect for a scout like you.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Show that you know the rope types used for rock climbing.
2. 2. Show that you know how to fit a climbing helmet and harness and how to tie in correctly.
3. 3. Show you understand the calls used in climbing.
4. 4. Show that you know how to abseil down a face. It should usually be at least 10 metres high.
5. 5. Take part in four or more separate climbs.
6. 6. Explain the safety rules for climbing on both natural and artificial rock faces.
7. 7. Show that you’re aware of environmental  issues around climbing on natural rock faces.
8. 8. Explain how to care for the equipment you used.

Description: Communication can help us reach out to more people, from longer distances and using a wide range of languages. Work towards your Communicator badge and help bring people closer together.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Radio communication:
1. Radio Amateur Licence (Foundation, Intermediate or Full)

Radio communication:
1. Learn the regulations governing the use of amateur radio equipment.
2. Visit an amateur radio station.
3. Log 25 different amateur radio stations. Note the date, time, call sign, frequency, readability and location. You may include some broadcast stations.
4. Show how to tune a simple communications receiver.
5. Give an example of a typical greetings message.
6. Explain in simple terms how radio waves travel around the world.
7. Learn the more commonly used HF and VHF amateur frequency bands.
8. Learn the phonetic alphabet and define at least eight international Q code signals.
9. Show that you can recognise call signs from the UK and near continent.

Communication codes:
1. Send and receive a short message by Morse code or semaphore at a rate of five words per minute.
2. Show that you know the proper procedure for sending and receiving a message.
3. Learn the International Phonetic Alphabet and define at least eight international Q code signals.
4. Construct a simple Morse code oscillator and send a short message.

Mobile and internet communication:
1. Show you know how to use your mobile safely and how to keep it safe.
2. Learn the meaning of these terms: SMS, MMS, 3G, 4G, WAP and Bluetooth.
3. Send a creative text, multimedia or video message to invite a friend to a Scouts event.
4. Manage a mobile phone address book and set up groups of contacts.
5. Show you can text accurately at a rate of 50 characters per minute.
6. Show you know the meaning of some popular chat abbreviations.
7. Share photos and videos of a Scouting activity you’ve been involved with, using available technology.
8. Manage an email address book and set up groups of contacts.

Foreign languages:
1. Carry on a simple conversation for about 10 minutes.
2. Act as an interpreter for a visitor who does not speak your native language.
3. Write a letter of around 150 words.
4. After a few minutes of study, translate a paragraph of basic text.
5. Communicate with a person who does not speak your native language.

Translator:
1. Carry out a simple conversation for about 10 minutes.
2. Use sign language to describe a Scouting experience to another person.
3. Act as a translator for a short conversation between a sign language user and someone with no sign language experience.
4. Invite a sign language user to talk to your Troop about what it’s like to have impaired hearing or speech.
5. Help by translating for them during their visit.

Description: Unleash your crafty creativity and take your crafting skills to the next level.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Make or decorate one or more articles using, whenever possible, original design ideas.

Description: Experience the thrill of the ride! Make certain your cycling skills are top-knotch as you plan your next cycling adventure.
Requirements:
MANDATORY (all required):
1. Use a bicycle that is properly equipped. Keep it in good working order for at least six months.
2. Show that you can carry out essential maintenance and repairs

Bikeability:
1. Bikeability Level 2 or 3

Road Cycling:
1. Explain what extra precautions you should take when cycling in the dark or in wet weather. Show you understand why motor vehicles take longer to stop in the wet.
2. Learn the basics of first aid and what to do if an accident happens.
3. Develop a working knowledge of map reading. Orientate a map using a compass or conspicuous features. Estimate distances and times taken to travel.
4. Plan and carry out an all-day cycle ride of at least 40 kilometres (25 miles).
5. Complete one of these: a. Show you can control a cycle along a slalom course b.Show you understand the Highway Code, including road signs and helmet use

Off-road Cycling:
1. Show you understand the Mountain Bike Code of Conduct.
2. Show you can control your cycle over different types of terrain.
3. Show you're aware of the damage that may be caused to the environment through careless cycling across the countryside
4. Learn the basics of first aid, including the treatment of hypothermia and find out what to do in the case of an accident.
5. Gain a working knowledge of map reading. Orientate a map using a compass or conspicuous features. Estimate distances and times taken to travel
6. Plan and carry out an all-day ride of at least 30 kilometres (20 miles)

British Schools Cycling Association Award:
1. The Gold Trix Award of the British Schools Cycling Association

Level 3 Go-MTB Award:
1. Level 3 Go-MTB Award from Cycling Scotland, Sustrans, CTC or Scottish Cycling MBLA

Description: Build, Modify or Repair – Develop your DIY acumen, and learn how to deal with emergencies and tackle DIY projects
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Show you know about hazard symbols and signs (for dangers such as toxic, flammable, irritant, electrical danger or slippery surface)
2. Show you know about safety equipment (such as goggles, gloves, masks, ear defenders)
3. Show you know how and where to turn off mains supplies (such as water, electricity and gas) to the house.
4. Learn how to safely isolate individual electrical circuits at the consumer unit.
5. Show or explain how you would deal with four DIY emergencies.
6. Take an active part in two major DIY projects, indoors or outside.

Description: Get up and get in the water and have a go at this ancient and exciting Chinese team sport
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Learn the safety rules, the capsize drills, the water buddy system
2. 2. Learn the procedures for loading, numbering off, stopping, bracing the boat, forward and backward paddling.
3. 3. Learn the instructions and commands issued by The Dragon Boat Racing Association.
4. 4. Carry out practice training sessions for a minimum of two hours.
5. 5. Take part in a competitive or timed dragon boat event over a course of at least 250 metres.

Description: There’s a bright spark in us all. Master the clever systems and circuits to support modern life.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Identify a number of common electronic components that are shown to you.
2. 2. Describe the systems used for marking components with their values.
3. 3. Show that you know the symbols used to represent common components in circuit diagrams.
4. 4. Show that you’re aware of the safe working practices to be followed when handling electronic components, circuit boards and when soldering.
5. 5. Use a multimeter to measure voltage, current and resistance in a simple circuit.
6. 6. Talk about the main differences in the operation of digital and analogue circuits.
7. 7. Construct three simple circuits.
8. Show how to identify the polarity of a diode and a specific PIN on an integrated circuit.
9. 8. Explain the principles behind the operation of each circuit and the typical values of voltage and current found in each.
10. 9. Explain the possible uses of the three circuits you built.
11. 10. Talk about the uses and benefits of electronics in everyday life.

Description: Showcase your performing talent, accept a standing ovation and have fun mastering an original piece of entertainment.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

:
1. Write and plan some original entertainment.
2. Present the entertainment to an audience at a school, for your Troop or at a parents’ evening.
3. Rehearse the entertainment and make sure everyone has a job to do.

:
1. Take an active part in a Scout show or another production.

Description: Make a difference a play an active part in improving the environment in your local area. Complete the badge and help protect the environment for future generations.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Find out about an environmental issue that is important to your local community.
2. 2. Take part in an activity or project that improves local conservation.
3. 3. Get involved in a campaign to make others aware of an environmental issue.

Description: Perfect your walk, trot and canter. Showcase your horsemanship skills and create an emotional and trusted bond with your horse
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Show you can catch a pony from a field or stable and tack up for riding.
2. Walk, trot and canter a pony
3. Jump over small fences.
4. Groom your pony correctly and explain why it is necessary
5. Show you know how to take care of saddlery and other equipment
6. Find out about some of the basic health issues affecting horses and ponies, including worms and laminitis.
7. Show you have a basic knowledge of grass management. Show you recognise poisonous plants and the results of overgrazing
8. Talk about road safety for riding.
9. Explain why you need a hat, body protector, stirrup and other safety equipment

Description: Learn about the process behind the food on our plates. You'll get some hands-on practical experience and develop a deeper appreciation for the natural world.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Farming:
1. Learn about farming practices in your area
2. Find out about the organisation, as well as the daily and seasonal operations, of a farm of your choice. Make a note of practices relating to livestock, crops, cultivation, rotation, machinery and labour force.
3. Find photos to demonstrate the changes in farming practices that have taken place over a number of years. Explain the reasons for these.

Smallholding:
1. Cultivate an area of garden or an allotment for a specific length of time. Agree this beforehand with your leadership team.
2. Show you're successful in growing: three kinds of hardy annual flower, three kinds of vegetable and two kinds of bulbs, herbaceous plants, flowering shrubs or rose
3. Keep a record of the work you've done and the results you've achieved. This could include height records of the flowers, for example.

Livestock:
1. Keep any kind of livestock for at least three months.

Description: Learn the fire safety essentials. Master the precautionary measures to take to prevent a fire.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Explain what action should be taken and why, if you discover a fire has broken out in the home or at camp.
2. 2. Explain the process of combustion.
3. 3. Be aware of dangers in the home and understand the fire precautions necessary.
4. 4. Explain the benefits of installing smoke detectors.
5. 5. Learn what the dangers of campfires are and what precautions should be taken.
6. 6. Find out about the causes of heath and grass fires.
7. 7. Learn how to make an emergency call for the fire service.
8. 8. Identify different fire extinguisher types such as water, dry powder, foam and carbon dioxide.
9. 9. Find out what to do if a person’s clothes are on fire.
10. 10. Talk to your family about what to do in the event of a fire at home.

Description: Discover how to manage and identify trees – and help preserve our woodland.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Identify at least eight common types of tree that grow in your area, including both deciduous and coniferous.
2. 2. Find out how to identify trees using identification keys.
3. 3. Prepare the soil and successfully transplant a young tree.
4. 4. Find out how both natural woodland and commercial forests are managed.
5. 5. Show how to select, use and care for forestry equipment, and know the safety issues involved.
6. 6. Show how to fell and trim out a tree or lay a hedge.

Description: Become the inspiration for people to start supporting good causes.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Identify and organise a fundraising initiative.
2. 2. Think of a short reason that tells potential donors about your chosen cause.
3. 3. Set a target and a date by which you’ll have raised the money.
4. 4. Write a short report about your fundraising challenge and submit it to your leader, Troop Forum or Patrol Leaders’ Council.

Description: Discover the exciting adventure of geocaching, where you can enjoy the freedom of being outside and identifying new places. All you require is a handheld GPS device and a sense of fun.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Show that you know about the Global Positioning System (GPS).
2. 2. Programme a handheld GPS.
3. 3. Show that you know the difference between Ordnance Survey, and latitude and longitude coordinates.
4. 4. Using an Ordnance Survey map (1:25000 or 1:50000 scale) to plan a route of at least 4km that contains a minimum of 10 waypoints.
5. 5. Sign up to a geocaching website.
6. 6. Show that you understand the safety and environmental aspects of geocaching, such as the Highway Code, Countryside Code and the Geocaching Association of Great Britain (GAGB) guidelines.
7. 7. Find five geocaches using a GPS. At least three geocaches must be ‘multi-caches’, with at least two waypoints.
8. 8. With the help of an adult create two caches.

Description: Help make the world a better place, learn about important global issues and play your part in helping change the world.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Identify where your clothing or other belongings have been made.
2. 2. Investigate a recent natural disaster by looking at photos, news articles or videos online.
3. 3. Find out about an international sporting event and discuss with your Troop how sporting events can contribute to international peace and understanding.
4. 4. In small groups, learn about an international health issue and use a creative way to share what you have learnt with your Troop.
5. 5. Think about the rights that we have in the UK (like the right to vote, the right to go to school and equal gender rights).

Description: Whistle down the wind, increase your stamina and explore the UK's green and pleasant lands.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. With others, plan at least five one-day journeys of at least 14km in hilly country.
2. 2. Using Ordnance Survey maps, complete all the information you need to plan the route for each journey.
3. 3. Learn how to summon help in an emergency.
4. 4. Make sure you know the different types of  hazards you might come across.
5. 5. Before setting out, list the equipment that should be taken and explain how to use them correctly.
6. 6. During the journey, show how you use the map and compass.
7. 7. Show you're aware of ways to preserve the natural environment, such as avoiding erosion and conserving wildlife habitats.
8. 8. Show that you're aware of developments in technology, such as the Global Positioning System (GPS), digital mapping or waterproof maps.
9. 9. Show that you know the publication Safety on Mountains, published by the British Mountaineering Council

Description: Take part in a hobby and develop your skills. You could choose to develop your creative and artistic flair, play sports or take part in other pursuits.
Requirements:
Complete 1 of the following:
1. Take up a hobby or interest that you do not already have an activity badge for.Keep a record of your hobby for at least four months.
2. Make a collection or study of objects for at least four months.You could collect books or magazines, films, cards, key rings, figurines or similar.Talk to your Patrol Leader or your Troop about the collection or study you chose.Explain why you chose your objects and what you like about them.

Description: We prepare young people with skills for life. Each year we help over 460,000 girls and boys enjoy fun and adventure while developing skills to succeed. Do more. Learn more. Be more.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Hold the activity badge in your chosen activity.
2. 2. Know what a young person in your section has to do to achieve the activity badge, so that you can instruct them in that subject.
3. 3. Attend a training course covering the technical skills involved in the activity badge and the use of appropriate training methods.
4. 4. Assist with the training of other young people in your section in the subject, over a period of at least three months.

Description: Explore the culture and traditions of other countries. Your journey will broaden your horizons as you learn about different communities.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Find out about the World Scout Movement’s history and what it does today.
2. 2. Take part in a traditional craft or creative activity from another country.
3. 3. In a language other than your own, introduce yourself and say a few basic, useful, everyday phrases.
4. 4. Take part in one of an event individually or with the Troop and report back to other Scout.

Description: Discover a world of knowledge at your fingertips. Showcase your library catalogue knowledge and other librarian skills.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Show that you know how to look after books and e-readers.
2. 2. Show that you can use a library catalogue.
3. 3. Explain how fiction and non-fiction books are arranged on the shelves.
4. 4. Learn what is meant by a reference book or material.
5. 5. Show how you would search for information using the internet.
6. 6. Talk to your assessor about books you have read and why you enjoyed theminformation you found from books or websitesgetting books on the internet for e-readers.

Description: Develop your Lifesaver decision-making and planning skills. Become primed in understanding how to react in emergency situations.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Explain and, if you can, show how you would carry out a rescue from water
2. 2. Reach a recognised standard
3. 3. Explain and, if you can, show what you would do if a person or a pet fell through ice

Description: Get to know your local area like the back of your hand. Explore all its routes, roads and useful places.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Rural and suburban areas:
1. Show that you know the local area surrounding your home or Scout Headquarters, up to a radius of 2 kilometres in suburban districts and 5 kilometres in rural districts.
2. Use a street map to point out six locations from step 1. From your home or Scout Headquarters, show the quickest route to one of the places.

Urban:
1. Gain a general knowledge of what parts of the country are served from your local airport, mainline railway and coach stations.
2. Find out how to reach the local airport, mainline railway and coach stations, and major tourist attractions from your Scout Headquarters or home.
3. Show how to use a map of your district.
4. Use it to point out any six places of interest. Show how to get to these places from your Scout Headquarters or home.
5. Give clear directions to a place of interest 8 kilometres away, to a person travelling by car or public transport.
6. Find out which major local roads link to the motorway and A-road network and the main cities these roads serve.

Heritage:
1. Study an aspect of national history, local history or family heritage.
2. Over a period agreed with your leader, get involved in a project to help preserve some aspect of national or local heritage.

Description: Hone your combat skills in Martial Arts. Display a blend of strategy, strength and calmness under pressure.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Take part in a regular martial arts activity that’s recognised by your sports council for at least six months.
2. 2. Take part in a competition or demonstration and talk about your performance with an instructor.

Description: Shoot an arrow with precision, Fire a rifle with pinpoint accuracy or fence with Olympian finesse.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Attend regular training sessions in a relevant activity like fencing, shooting or archery.
2. 2. Learn the safety rules associated with your activity and show how to follow them.
3. 3. Take part in your chosen activity at an officially supervised contest.

Description: Fuel your imagination and develop problem-solving and critical thinking skills. Develop your practical vehicle maintenance knowledge.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Motor Car:
1. Learn the principles of operating an engine. Make sure you understand the function of the clutch, gearbox and rear axle differential.
2. Show how to check and refill the windscreen wash bottle of a car.
3. Show how to change a bulb at the front and in the rear light cluster of a car.
4. Show how to check the level of coolant in the radiator, ‘top up’ the radiator and explain the importance of anti-freeze.
5. Show how to check tyre pressures and inflate a tyre correctly.
6. Remove and replace a road wheel.
7. Explain what to look for when checking that a tyre conforms to the legal requirement. Find out why tyres with different amounts of wear should not be mixed on the same axle.
8. Show how to change a wiper blade.
9. Explain the outline requirements for an MOT road test.

Power Boat:
1. Power Boat Part 1
2. Power Boat Part 2

Aircraft:
1. Learn the basic principles of one these component parts and be able to point them out, an aircraft piston engine, an aircraft gas turbine engine.
2. Learn the basic principles of flight and airframe construction of a fixed wing aircraft.
3. Learn and then demonstrate Aircraft Marshalling signals used by day and night.
4. Show you can carry out any four of the taks

Motorcycle or scooter:
1. Learn the principles of operating an engine. Learn about the function of the clutch, gearbox, carburettor and transmission of a motorcycle.
2. Remove and replace a road wheel.
3. Check and top up the level of the engine oil.
4. Explain how to adjust the tension of the final drive chain.
5. Show how you change a bulb at the front and in the rear light cluster.
6. Show how you would check tyre pressures and inflate a tyre correctly.
7. Explain what to look for when checking that a tyre conforms to the legal requirement.
8. Explain the outline requirements for an MOT road test.

Description: Develop your eye for a compelling story and generate ‘hooks’ to draw in audiences. Become a creative storyteller, and get media coverage for your story.
Requirements:
Complete 3 of the following:
1. 1. Produce and give a presentation about Scouting.
2. 2. Write a press release about a Scout event that has taken place.
3. 3. Find out about local media outlets such as radio, TV, newspapers and online.
4. 4. Prepare and present an audio or video package about a Scouting event or activity.
5. 5. Prepare a creative display about your Troop or Group that can be exhibited in your local library, information centre or public place.
6. 6. Interview a local public figure or someone in the local news, such as a church leader, politician or celebrity and present the interview to your Troop.
7. 7. Produce some media which can be used within Scouting, such as a district newsletter story or a piece of website content.

Description: Rain or shine, wind or snow – ignite your passion for the weather.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Explain how each of these are measured:Wind force and direction, Cloud type and extent, Temperature, Pressure, Rainfall, Humidity
2. 2. Record the weather conditions every day for two weeks, or once a week for three months.
3. 3. Identify different cloud types.
4. 4. What do ‘warm’ and ‘cold’ air masses in summer and winter do to the typical weather in your area?
5. 5. Explain how weather forecasts are created.
6. 6. Show that you understand a synoptic weather map, including fronts and isobars.

Description: Show your creativity and attention to detail as you become an expert Model Maker.
Requirements:
Complete 1 of the following:
1. Model aeroplanes
2. Model boats
3. Model cars
4. Model trains
5. General model making

Description: Learn how to be confident in decisions around money.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Learn about how money is used online.
2. 2. Learn how to budget and make smart choices with your money.
3. 3. Find out how saving and borrowing money works.
4. 4. Explore how money can affect your feelings and wellbeing.

Description: Develop a deeper aptitude of your beliefs and how they help to guide you through all the stages of your life
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Take an active part in your place of worship.
2. 2. Find out more about the origins of your faith.
3. 3. Explore something about the history of your faith at a local, national or international level.
4. 4. Explain to an adult some of the teachings of your faith.

Description: Become a great Naturalist and play your part in preserving the natural world as a whole.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. With appropriate permission investigate the wildlife and plants found
2. 2. Tell a knowledgeable adult what you discovered.
3. 3. Find out more about a plant, animal or particular wildlife from your chosen location.
4. 4. Discuss what you found out, giving sources for information from places like museums, field guides or the internet.
5. 5. Discuss how human activities or land management can affect wildli

Description: Find your way from one point to another, using only a map, a compass and your brain
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Learn about the map colours and common symbols used on an orienteering map.
2. 2. Orientate a map using either terrain or a compass.
3. 3. Complete three courses at orienteering events recognised by British Orienteering or another similar standard.
4. 4. Show you know the safety procedures, basic first aid, appropriate clothing and equipment for countryside navigation.
5. 5. Show that you know the Countryside Code.

Description: Take flight and experience the thrill of parascending. Adventure awaits!
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Take part in a parascending course.
2. Learn the main characteristics and different types of parachutes used by  parascenders.
3. 3. Show a basic knowledge of the theory of flight.
4. 4. Experience at least four parascending flights.

Description: Take an image, freeze a moment, and discover the art of photography.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Still photography:
1. 12 photos or 6 B&W photos
2. Show that you know the main settings on a digital camera or a smartphone camera.
3. Describe what accessories are available to use with digital cameras or smartphone cameras.
4. Edit a selection of your images, using editing software on a computer or using an app on a smartphone.
5. Diagnose typical faults that happen at the photographing or editing stages, such as over or under exposure and high or low contrast.
6. Show that you know how to care for a digital camera or smartphone camera.

Video photography:
1. Produce at least two short films
2. Show that you understand: camera techniques & production techniques
3. Show that you know how to care for a video camera and accessories, such as storage media, batteries, microphones and lights or discuss the differences between recording video on a video camera, digital camera and a smartphone.

Description: Have fun and take part in a physical activity and improve both your body and mind.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Regularly take part in an active sport or physical pursuit, which you haven’t already gained an activity badge for.
2. 2. Show a reasonable level of skill in your sport or pursuit.
3. 3. Explain the rules or guidelines that govern the sport or pursuit you chose.
4. 4. Show how you would prepare before taking part in your sport or pursuit.
5. 5. Explain how to care for the equipment you use.

Description: Master your pioneering skills in using ropes, wooden spars and knots. Become a key member of your team as you create amazing structures.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. As a member of a group, take part in an indoor pioneering project, like constructing a catapult or chariot
2. As a member of a group, take part in an outdoor pioneering project, like building a monkey bridge, a raft or parallel runway
3. Show the correct way to do a whipping or safe rope sealing
4. Show the correct way to splice a rope
5. Show the correct way to coil and store a rope
6. Show the correct way to use levers to extract objects or move heavy weights
7. Show the correct way to be safe in pioneering projects. Explain why it's important
8. Name and tie at least six knots and three lashings that are useful in pioneering

Description: Have fun on the water by mastering the waterways in your chosen boat.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. choose and identify the boat you will use
2. choose the waters you will visit
3. identify the features and hazards of this water
4. learn what the rules are for boating on the water you're using
5. wear the proper clothing and make sure you have the correct equipment for your craft
6. Locate the engine and know how to start and stop it safely.
7. Take part in a man overboard drill.
8. Launch and recover your craft (if that’s possible) and come alongside. Moor and berth your craft.
9. Control the speed and direction of your craft to steer around a course or on a journey.

Description: Take a stroke, cut through the water, and become a rowing master.
Completion Rules: 2 from Equipment + 7 from Safety + 4 from Manoeuvres + 2 from Tasks
Requirements:
Equipment (complete 2):
1. Point out and name the basic parts of a pulling boat
2. Explain the importance of wearing appropriate clothing for various weather conditions

Safety (complete 7):
1. Understand how to safely enter and exit the boat
2. Understand the safety equipment required and how to use it
3. Gain a basic knowledge of the rules of the road for your local waters
4. Understand the difference between a lifejacket and a buoyancy aid, and demonstrate how to wear them correctly
5. From a boat, heave an unweighted line to land within reach of target five metres, within three attempts
6. Learn the actions and safety requirements to take when being towed
7. Know how to respond in an emergency

Manoeuvres (complete 4):
1. Take the boat away from a bank side mooring
2. Row in a straight line for 100 metres
3. Complete a figure-of-eight course
4. Come alongside in your dinghy, to moor at a ring, post, bollard or buoy, using a round turn and two half hitches

Tasks (complete 2):
1. Cull over the stern between two points, 20 metres apart, and turn through 180 degrees
2. Draw stroke over the bow
3. Take a place as an oarsman, including stroke
4. Give boat orders effectively, or listen to boat orders and act on them
5. As bowman, be a lookout and report hazards to the coxswain using standard maritime directions, such as starboard, port quarter and dead ahead

Description: Keep your scout troop well stocked with supplies by discovering what it takes to be a great quartermaster.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Assist:
1. Show ability in the listed areas
2. Keep a simple record showing equipment issued and returned.
3. Show you understand that general tidiness is the secret of good quartermastering.

Nights Away:
1. During the experience show you’re capable in at least three areas
2. Keep simple records, showing the equipment issued and returned.
3. Keep a portable first aid kit well stocked and maintained.
4. Choose tools to take to camp, to complete emergency repairs on equipment.
5. Show you understand that general tidiness is the secret of good quartermastering.

Description: Spark your curiosity and creativity with the Scientist activity badge. Have fun learning some valuable science-based skills.
Requirements:
Choose 1 of the following options:

Option 1:
1. Explore and discuss the science behind two Scouting activities or hobbies.
2. Complete one of the options. Plan and complete your own experiment to explore the science behind one Scouting activity or hobby. Record your findings and explain what these mean to others.
Try thinking of a question you want to answer or something you want to prove. Plan and run an activity, demonstration or presentation to help others understand the science behind a Scouting activity or hobby.

Option 2:
1. Plan and complete three science experiments or activities.
2. Find out how one of your experiments or activities links to the real world.

Description: Discover what things are out there in our universe and learn how to navigate with the stars. How would you travel through space to make new discoveries?
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Find out what happens to an astronaut's body in space. Learn how the lack of gravity affects their body, and what they do to stay fit.
2. 2. Learn about the speed of light and how we use light years to measure distances in space.
3. 3. Discover how different space technologies have helped us to understand and explore the universe.
4. 4. Find out what a black hole is, how it forms and how we can detect where they are in space.
5. 5. Discover something new about the universe and share it with the group.
6. 6. You can use the stars to find your way. Explore how you can navigate using stars and constellations.
7. 7. Imagine you’re planning an expedition to a distant solar system. Design how you’ll travel there and think about what you will need to take with you.

Description: If you follow a sport, rather than take part, you can prove your expert knowledge through this badge. You can choose anything from football or basketball to archery, motor racing or water polo.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Explain the rules governing your favourite sport.
2. 2. Describe the levels of achievement within your chosen sport locally, nationally or internationally.
3. 3. Show that you know some of the personalities, champions or other experts in your chosen sport.
4. 4. Talk about the equipment needed for the sport.
5. 5. Describe a recent major event, championship or landmark in the sport.
6. 6. Explain how you follow your sport. How do you keep up to date with developments?

Description: Be spontaneous, improvise and show your creativity. Take up the challenge and get involved in a street sport like skateboarding, in-line skating or Parkour.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. 1. Take part in a street sport like skateboarding, roller or in-line skating, Parkour or another street sport agreed by your leadership team.
2. 2. Own or use equipment for a street sport.
3. 3. Explain how to care for the equipment used and explain what you should look out for when equipment is nearing the end of its life.
4. 4. Show that you’re skilled in your chosen street sport and show how you’ve improved over three months.
5. 5. Explain the safety rules for your chosen sport including where to undertake street sports safely and responsibly.

Description: Be prepared for the unexpected! Develop your survival skills to be self-reliant in tough conditions and an awareness of natural resources and how to use them.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Show that you know how to give first aid treatment you may need to use while on a survival event, considering you may have limited resources available
2. Show how to construct different kinds of shelter
3. Show how to build a fire and use basic lighting techniques. You should not use man-made materials such as paper or firelighters.
4. Show how to maintain hygiene in a survival situation
5. Show basic knife or multi-tool skills, including safety and sharpening and maintenance
6. Show the correct use of international distress signals, using a whistle, torch, mirror or markers
7. Show some basic actions to take while waiting rescue that will both keep you (and your group) safe and will assist your rescuers in locating you
8. Put together a personal survival kit.
9. With a group of at least three Scouts, take part in a survival exercise

Description: From scuba diving to water skiing, hit the water and indulge your passion, for a fantastic water activities experience.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Reach one of the required standards

Description: Discover the true meaning to the world’s different faiths, so you can find common ground in your personal relationships.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. One activity from Part 1
2. One activity from Part 2
3. 3. Read a text from a faith that you are not familiar with
4. Find out how following the teachings of a particular faith affects an individual’s daily life

Description: Develop the craft of storytelling through writing. Reach into your imagination and you could be the next Philip Pullman or Cressida Cowell.
Requirements:
Complete 4 of the following:
1. Compose a poem of at least eight lines. Discuss its meaning and construction.
2. Create a short story of around 600 words.
3. Write a descriptive passage of around 600 words on a subject, agreed with an appropriate adult beforehand.
4. Write a 600-word review of a favourite book, play or other work of literature and talk about it with an appropriate adult.
5. Produce a published article of around 600 words in length.
6. You could contribute to a school, faith, community or Scout magazine or write a letter to a local paper.
7. Keep a diary on a subject, for a length of time agreed with an appropriate adult beforehand.
8. Write a play or dramatic sketch lasting at least 10 minutes.
9. Interview a local celebrity, or other notable person.
10. Write a letter to a pen pal (real or imaginary) of at least 600 words.

Description: Abseil down a mountain! Sail down a river! Hover on a hovercraft! It’s time to embrace four new adventurous activities, and see where they take you
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Take part in four different adventurous activities.
2. Show how you have developed your skill and expertise in one of these activities.
3. Learn about any environmental issues caused by your activity.
4. Research other ways you can take part, or develop your skills, in your chosen activities.

Description: This is the highest award a Scout can earn. To complete it, you need to complete all nine of the Challenge Awards, plus six Activity badges
Requirements:
PREREQUISITE BADGES (all required):
1. World
2. Adventure
3. Creative
4. Expedition
5. Outdoor
6. Personal
7. Skills
8. Team Leader
9. Teamwork

PLUS 6 Activity or Staged Activity Badges of your choice

Description: Whether you’re trying your hand at web design or mastering an ancient craft like needlework, take your creative skills to the next level and make something extraordinary from scratch.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Over a period of time, take part in at least four creative activities.
2. Show that you have developed your skills in one of these activities.
3. Use your creative ability to produce something that promotes a Scouting activity or an event.
4. Construct a model using materials like a plastic kit or recycled items.
5. Show how to use social media or the internet in a creative and safe way.
6. Take part in a performance.

Description: Are you ready for your next big adventure? Take part in a two-day expedition or exploration, in the UK or abroad
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Take part in either an expedition or an exploration over two days with at least three other Scouts.
2. Take an active part in planning the expedition or exploration
3. During the expedition or exploration: Play a full part in the team, Use a map or other navigation device to keep track of where you are, Cook and eat at least one hot meal, Do a task, investigation, or exploration as agreed with your Leader.
4. Produce an individual report or presentation within the three weeks following your expedition or exploration.

Description: Spend eight nights away from home. Cook a meal on camp. Tread new ground. It’s time to find your feet in the great outdoors
Requirements:
MANDATORY (all required):
1. Take an active part in at least eight nights away as a Scout
2. With others, pitch and strike your tent
3. Lead, or help to lead, a group of Scouts to set up a well-organised site
4. Prepare and light an open fire or set up a suitable stove.
5. Understand the three points of the Countryside Code.
6. Find out why personal and campsite hygiene is important
7. Using knots that you have learned, build a simple pioneering project, object or camp gadget
8. Explore the environment of your camp and make sure you know where everything is.
9. Find out what accidents and incidents can happen outdoors or during your camp.
10. Show how to use an axe, saw or knife safely.

PLUS 4 of the following:
1. Provide a service commitment to the site for about an hour.
2. Take part in a wide game.
3. Take part in a campfire or other entertainment.
4. Working with others, successfully complete a two-hour activity or project.
5. Plan a balanced menu for a short camp.
6. Lead the cooking of a meal for the group.
7. Show how to pack a rucksack correctly, with appropriate kit for the camp or event.
8. Cook a backwoods meal with the group.
9. Build a bivouac and sleep in it.
10. Show that you know the safety precautions for using lamps and stoves.

Description: Everyone has a different idea of what a challenge looks like. Choose two you'd love to accomplish and dive right in
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Challenge 1
2. Challenge 2

Description: Everyone has to start somewhere, and practice makes perfect. Hone your skills over a six-week period, and see how quickly you will soar!
Requirements:
MANDATORY (all required):
1. Regularly take part in physical activities over a period of four to six weeks.
2. Take part in at least three activities that require a number of problem-solving skills.
3. Show you understand why eating a sensible diet and getting enough sleep is important
4. Do some research so that you can explain the dangers and harmful effects of smoking, alcohol and drugs

PLUS 5 of the following:
1. Mend or customise an item of clothing
2. Cook and serve a two-course meal, for at least four people
3. Fix a puncture or a dropped chain on a bike
4. Wash up after a meal, making sure everything is clean and dry
5. Use a washing machine to wash a load of clothes
6. Iron your uniform shirt
7. Change a lightbulb, in a ceiling light
8. Set a heating timer and thermostat as needed for the time of year
9. Clean a toilet, hob or oven
10. Do another similar home skill

Description: Learn how to lead by example and take one for the team!
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Successfully lead a Scout team at a camp or all day event.
2. Help a new Scout to be part of the Troop with an understanding of what is expected of them.
3. Help another Scout to develop a Scouting skill.
4. Represent the views of other Scouts.

Description: Two hands are better than one. Four hands are better than two. Work with your fellow Scouts over a three-month period, and achieve something truly awesome together.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. On at least three separate occasions, be part of a Scout team, where you work together to achieve a goal.
2. Give at least three examples of when you’ve been in different types of teams.
3. Take part in at least three team building activities that you have not tried before.
4. Take an active part in at least four Troop or Patrol Forums.

Description: Whether you’re volunteering in your local community or learning about an international issue, this award is all about exploring the world from your doorstep and making a positive impact.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Choose an aspect of local community life and find out as much as you can about it.
2. Spend a day volunteering with and finding out about a service in your local community:
3. Take part in an activity that reflects upon and explores your own beliefs, attitudes and values (this may or may not include religious beliefs).
4. Take part in an activity that explores common beliefs and attitudes towards gender or disability in different societies
5. Take an active part in an environmental project.
6. Investigate and try to make contact with Scouts in another country.
7. Take part in an activity that explores an international issue.

Description: In their Troop, Scouts join a Patrol - a smaller group led by a Patrol Leader and Assistant Patrol Leader. These older Scouts handle leadership duties like welcoming newcomers and running activities. Some Troops also have Senior Patrol Leaders with extra responsibilities. All leaders wear distinctive stripes to show their roles.
Requirements: No formal requirements - awarded by leader discretion

Choose 1 of the following options:

Champions for Nature:
1. Identify the need
2. Plan action
3. Take action
4. Learn and make more change
5. Tell the world

Go Solar:
1. Identify the need
2. Plan action
3. Take action
4. Learn and make more change
5. Tell the world

Tide Turners:
1. Identify the need
2. Plan action
3. Take action
4. Learn and make more change
5. Tell the world

Description: Once you've made your Promise, you'll earn your Membership Award, featuring an image of the fleur de lis. This is the international Scout symbol, worn by Scouts all over the world.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Know about the Scout Troop
2. Know about joining your Troop
3. Become a Scout by making the Promise

Description: Eventually, it'll be time to embrace your next adventure. Explorers awaits.
Requirements: No formal requirements - awarded by leader discretion

Description: In their Troop, Scouts join a Patrol - a smaller group led by a Patrol Leader and Assistant Patrol Leader. These older Scouts handle leadership duties like welcoming newcomers and running activities. Some Troops also have Senior Patrol Leaders with extra responsibilities. All leaders wear distinctive stripes to show their roles.
Requirements: No formal requirements - awarded by leader discretion

Description: In their Troop, Scouts join a Patrol - a smaller group led by a Patrol Leader and Assistant Patrol Leader. These older Scouts handle leadership duties like welcoming newcomers and running activities. Some Troops also have Senior Patrol Leaders with extra responsibilities. All leaders wear distinctive stripes to show their roles.
Requirements: No formal requirements - awarded by leader discretion

Description: This badge is all about thinking about what you want to achieve, setting a goal and making it happen. Complete at least one of the following requirements.
Requirements:
Complete ALL of the following:
1. Choose one thing you’d like to change, improve or deliver for young people in your Troop or section, and make it happen. This could be learning or teaching a new skill, developing your current talents or interests, or changing something about Scouts.

Description: Now it's time to take the lead – think supporting others, delivering your programme and nights away. Complete at least one of the following requirements.
Requirements:
Complete 1 of the following:
1. Lead a session that shows older Cubs the best of Scouts.
2. Lead a session for your Troop.
3. Lead a Troop Forum for your section.
4. Lead a one night camp with no adult volunteers. You’ll need a Nights Away Events Passport.

Description: This badge is all about thinking creatively, working together and planning some exciting activities for your programme.
Requirements:
Complete 1 of the following:
1. Plan an event for your Scout group.
2. Think of an idea that’ll help your Troop achieve a badge and share it in a Troop Forum.
3. Plan a term of activities with your leader.
4. Create a series of activities that help other Scouts to achieve a badge.

Description: Think about how you’ll represent your group – you could engage your community, invite some friends to join the fun or chat to your Trustee Boards.  Complete at least one of the following requirements.
Requirements:
Complete 1 of the following:
1. Talk with your Group or District Trustee Board about how Scouts could be improved in your group or District.
2. Lead a Scouts activity for young people who aren’t involved in Scouts.
3. Take part in a project with young people from across your group that uses skills you’ve learned at Scouts to help people in your community.
4. Plan and deliver a Scouts activity for a local decision maker to take part in and show them why they should support Scouts in your area.
